Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Robots Designed to Assist During Nuclear Catastrophes - Autonomously Creating 3-D Maps, Collecting Radiation/Other Data at Japan's Fukushima Nuclear Plants

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project advances the state-of-the-art of autonomous Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) algorithms, and maximizes the ability to explore under extreme conditions with minimal time using real-time 3D methods in nuclear power plants. The integrated system consists of a hardware system with three LIDAR's, a CPU, a GPU, a battery and a wireless unit.

The state-of-the-art in nuclear power plant disaster mitigation is a direct consequence, as well as the development of more advanced and robust SLAM techniques that are applicable in all domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rescue robots which are operating in the Tokyo Electric Power Company's (TEPCO) failed nuclear plants at Fukushima are operated manually. The goal of this project was to demonstrate that rescue robots can be operated autonomously for the next nuclear or other disasters thereby reducing the risk to personnel. The robots at Fukushima are used to monitor the radiation levels and photograph/map debris in the plants, but they cannot function properly in this high humidity environment which quickly fogs up the lens on the mounted camera. The walls of the plant buildings could be 1m in thickness, so the wireless connection is inevitably unstable. In addition, the robots are teleoperated using a joystick, so the training of a robot operator is indispensable. A better alternative for future rescue robots would be the technology developed in this project.

As an outcome of the project, an accurate and efficient Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) technology, the grid-based scan-to-map matching SLAM, has been implemented into robots to allow the map-based teleoperation in a dark, humid environment and semi-autonomous return at communication loss. Prior research has not developed robots which can effectively operate during this disaster, controlling the robots manually only via wires and a joystick, whilst the nuclear environments are highly complex and challenging. This was because research focus has been more on the advancement of novel technologies while the implemented technologies have been limited to those that have been conservatively proven. This project was the first step in autonomous rescue robots and follow-up research would enhance these capabilities.

As noted in the NSF review guidelines, the NSF goal is to “To promote the progress of science; to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare; to secure the national defense; and for other purposes”. This project is unique since (1) the SLAM technology advanced the state-of-the-art for real-time SLAM used for navigation of autonomous robots and (2) the results were disseminated at both the ICIUS 2011 conference in Tokyo and on the Internet http://www.cmsvt.org/. Also this research provides potential technology which permits rescue robots to operate autonomously during future nuclear power plant and other disasters so that robots rather than humans are in harm’s way.
